title: National Heritage Conservation Commission (Membo Caves) (National Monument) (Declaration) Order, 2023
content:
18th August, 2023 Statutory Instruments 207
GOVERNMENT OF ZAMBIA
STATUTORY INSTRUMENT NO. 34 OF 2023
The National Conservation Commission Act
(Laws, Volume 12, Cap. 173)
The National Conservation Commission (Membo Caves)
(National Monument) (Declaration) Order, 2023
IN EXERCISE of the powers contained in Section 27 of The National
Heritage Conservation Commission Act the following order is made:
1. This Order may be cited as the National Heritage Title
Conservation Commission (Membo Caves) (National Monument)
(Declaration) Order, 2023.
2. The heritage described in the Schedule is declared a national Declaration
monument. of National
Monument
Copies of this Statutory Instrument can be obtained from the Government Printer,
P.O. Box 30136, 10101 Lusaka. Price K4.00 each.
208 Statutory Instruments 18th August, 2023
SCHEDULE
(Paragraph 2)
MEMBO CAVE
LOCATION
This site is located at the north end of Kilwa Island in Nshimba (Nsimba) Chiefdom on Lake
Mweru in Nchelenge District of the Luapula Province of Zambia, at 914’48’’S, 28°23’4’’E.
STATEMENT OF SIGNIFICANCE
This site is the only known lacustrine cave system in the Republic, formed and located in a
freshwater lake, and it measures about 50 metres in length with a height of up to 5 metres. This
site occurs within part of the extension of the Great East African Rift Valley System. The
geomorphological features of the site include a vertical shaft descending from the top with
stalagmites and stalactites. There is a hidden approach to the site, from the water’s edge in the
generally whitish-greyish scenic cliffs which is infested by crocodiles.
This site is of historical significance as it has been reported to have been used as a hiding
place, among other uses, during the days of the slave trade and is part of the Greater Slave
Route to East Africa.
BOUNDARY DESCRIPTION
The boundary for this site starts from Point A at latitude 9°14’40.1"S, longitude 28°23’34’’E
and following the shoreline of Kilwa Island on Lake Mweru in an easterly direction, the
boundary line meets Point B at latitude 9°14’50’’S, longitude 28°23’51’’E and in a southerly
direction to Point C at latitude 9°15’8’’S, longitude 28°23’45E and through to Point D at
latitude 9°15’17.29’’S, longitude 28°23’24’’E in a south-westerly direction and connecting to
Point E at latitude 9°15’16’’S, longitude 28°23’22’’E on the western shoreline of the island;
thence in a northerly direction along the shoreline to the starting point.
The site boundary encompasses a total landmass and surface area of 60.5 hectares.
The specified area is shown on a plan marked red, signed by the Surveyor General and
deposited in the office of the Surveyor-General and the National Heritage Conservation
Commission, Lusaka.
R. SIKUMBA,
Minister of Tourism
LUSAKA
11th August, 2023
[MOT.13/7/1]
